instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing power rails
threads.message: Hi Guys, I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> where all the power rails pulls, even PPBUS goes to 8.13 and back to 8.59. I do have green and orange line. Looks like it tries to start, but not. At <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> I also have pulses on <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, S4 and 3.3V lines.Board looks pretty clean.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing power rails
threads.message:
CPU VCORE pulses too?
Check for short on S3/0 power rails, beyond the Power FETS.
Did you try SMC bypass mode?
3V42 steady?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing power rails
threads.message:
CPU VCore = no pulse
3V42 = Steady
Checking for shorts now

Could you remind me how to do SMC bypass please? I google it first (ofcourse...) but only find SMC reset and forgot!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing power rails
threads.message: ok, found a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, diving into the rabit hole :), not too many IC in this circuit though....!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing power rails
threads.message: Update: found the short lead to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>, replaced <CAPACITOR>C7600</CAPACITOR> where smoke was coming out, short is gone. I still have a pulse on lines, checked at <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and also pulsing. <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> has 32mhz.
